Say, gentle Youthe, that tread'st untouch'd with Care,</br>Where Nature hathe so guerdon'd Bathe's gay Scene;</br>Fedde with the Songe that daunceth in the Sire;</br>'Midst fairest Wealthe of Flora's Magazine;</br>Hathe Eye or Eare yet founde, thine Steppes to blesse,</br>That Gem of Life, y-clep'd True Happinesse?

With Beautie restes she not; — nor Woes to lighte</br>Her hallowde Taper at proude Honour's Flame;</br>Nor Circe's Cuppe dothe crown; nor comes in Flighte</br>Upon th' Icarian Winge of bablinge Fame;</br>Not Shrine of Golde doth this fair Sainte embower,</br>She glides from Heav'n, but not in Danae's Shower.

Go Blossome, wanton in suche joyous Aire,</br>But, ah! — eft soone thy buxome Blaste is o'er!</br>When the sleek Pate shall grow far 'bove its Haire,</br>And creeping Age shall reape this piteous Lore;</br>To broode o'er Follie, and with me confesse,</br>"Earthe's flatt'ringe Dainties prove but sweete Distresse."</br>
